title: Twenty-two vows of Ambedkar
text:
The Twenty-two vows or twenty-two pledges are the 22 Buddhist vows administered by <a href="B.%20R.%20Ambedkar">B. R. Ambedkar</a>, the <a href="Dalit%20Buddhist%20movement">revivalist of Buddhism in India</a>, to his followers. On converting to <a href="Buddhism">Buddhism</a>, Ambedkar made 22 vows, and asked his 600,000 supporters to do the same. After receiving <a href="Buddhist%20initiation%20ritual">lay ordination</a>, Ambedkar gave "<a href="dharma">dhamma</a> diksha" to his followers. The ceremony included 22 vows administered to all new converts after <a href="Three%20Jewels">Three Jewels</a> and <a href="Five%20Precepts">Five Precepts</a>. On 14 October 1956 at <a href="Nagpur">Nagpur</a>, Ambedkar performed another mass religious conversion ceremony at <a href="Chandrapur">Chandrapur</a>.
It is believed by <a href="Navayana">Ambedkarite Buddhists</a> that these vows are the guidelines of the social revolution that motivates human instincts. These vows demonstrate both the <a href="social%20movement">social movement</a> aspect of <a href="Navayana%20Buddhism">Navayana Buddhism</a>, and demonstrate its core deviation from earlier <a href="Schools%20of%20Buddhism">sects of Buddhism</a>. In India, these vows are taken as an oath by individuals or groups of people when they convert to Buddhism.

The vows marble stone.
Considering the historical significance of these twenty-two vows, the then president of "Dr. Babasaheb Ambedkar Deekshabhoomi Memorial Committee", and former Governor of Bihar and Kerala <a href="R.%20S.%20Gavai">R. S. Gavai</a> and Sadanand Fulzele, the secretary of the organization, have carved these 22 vows on a wide marble stone at the Deekshabhoomi ground and placed the pillar at the first sight of the stupa. At a <a href="Peace_Pagoda%23Wardha%2C_India">Buddha Vihara at Wardha</a>, under M. L. Kasare's leadership, a similar grand pillar has been erected. According to the <a href="2011%20Census%20of%20India">2011 Census of India</a>, Ambedkarite Navayana Buddhists comprise about 87% (7.3 million) of Indian Buddhist community, and nearly 90% (6.5 million) of all Navayana Buddhists in India live in a single state, <a href="Maharashtra">Maharashtra</a>.
